awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: X-rays, 3D animation and human locomotion
awd_abstract_narration:
Walking efficiently on two legs (bipedalism) is considered a defining characteristic of modern humans, and researchers have long strived to understand how, when, and why human bipedalism evolved. The discoveries of fossilized footprints made by living, moving individuals offer a promising source of data on hominin locomotion to complement what can be learned from fossilized skeletal remains. In this study, X-ray imaging, 3D animation, and computer simulation methods are developed and applied to understand formation of this bipedal record. Such foundational research is required to reconstruct foot anatomy and motion from fossil footprints, and to evaluate competing evolutionary hypotheses about bipedalism. The project represents an interdisciplinary collaboration between primarily undergraduate and major research institutions, with substantial training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. Student recruitment will focus on groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields. Results will be translated into pedagogical materials focused on the intersection of science and visual art, and the public will be engaged through museum and media science outreach.

Previous studies have developed methods for interpreting aspects of foot anatomy and motion from human footprints, but none have approached the problem mechanistically to understand the complex foot-substrate interactions through which footprints are formed. Direct observation of these interactions has not been possible because human feet and deformable substrates are both opaque, and contact areas are therefore hidden when a foot sinks to form a footprint. Here, biplanar X-ray, 3D animation, and computer simulation methods will be developed to visualize and analyze movement as individuals walk through substrates to create footprints. Direct mechanistic knowledge of foot-substrate interactions is potentially transformative for paleoanthropologists to extract anatomical and functional inferences from fossil human footprints and use these to test evolutionary hypotheses. Further, new imaging and analysis techniques are readily transferrable to other organisms, and may transform other approaches across animal biomechanics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Moving on two legs (bipedalism) is considered one of the defining traits of our human ancestry. The origins of this mode of locomotion remain controversial, in part because skeletal fossils are fragmentary and open to different interpretations. Fossil footprints (tracks) are recognized as an alternate source of evidence, but our limited understanding of track shape remains a major obstacle.  This project sought to break open fundamental aspects of the track formation process in a mechanistic way. How do specific features of human footprints arise within the creation of a single track, and what can fossil tracks reveal about foot anatomy and bipedal locomotion?

Over the last four years, the collaboration developed and refined methods for recording, analyzing, and simulating human footprint formation. Data from 12 subjects were collected as they walked on solid ground and various muds between two X-ray beams, which recorded the motion of approximately 100 small beads attached to their feet. Video analysis yielded marker movements employed to accurately animate a 3-D model of a subject’s foot in relation to a 3-D model of their track. Actual foot movements were also used to drive computer simulations in order to understand how virtual substrates flow into the final track shape.

The project's results can be divided into two related categories. First, the collaboration made significant methodological advances in visualizing and quantifying changes in foot shape while underground. High-resolution foot animations of unrivaled quality then fostered extremely realistic virtual footprint simulations (Hatala et al., 2021). Second, the collaborators explored the complex relationship between foot shape, foot motion, substrate consistency and track shape. Tracks are not simple molds of static anatomy, but dynamic records of a sequence of foot postures and the forces they transfer to the ground. The project's most compelling finding was the almost complete disconnect between the arch of a subject’s foot and the arch of their tracks (Hatala et al., 2023). Contrary to previous interpretations, it was discovered that arched tracks do not reflect foot anatomy; even the lowest arched subjects could create highly arched tracks. Rather, arched tracks are produced by a specific heel-toe motion pattern, which in deep mud can produce arches up to eight times larger than the foot that made them. When a new volumetric method of measuring arches was applied to fossil hominin tracks, those from the famous Laetoli site were found to be lower and far more variably arched, indicating a heel-toe pattern significantly different from those in modern humans.

Over the duration of the project, The collaboration provided undergraduate training at several levels. PI Gatesy participated in a joint course (“Virtual Reality Design for Science”) for Brown and Rhode Island School of Design students, providing human foot motion and track simulation data for visualization. One Brown undergraduate participated in an REU, learning how to run track simulations based on X-ray-derived foot motion data. A second Brown undergraduate was trained in video analysis and 3-D animation, as well as X-ray recording; they are currently completing an Honors Thesis on human track formation. Finally, several undergraduates from Chatham University received training and mentoring during one week visits to Brown each summer once the pandemic allowed.
